title: McEwan to focus on culture and cost
text:
Perhaps because of the depths of problems at RBS and the intense public scrutiny of the bank – it is, after all, still two-thirds owned by the British taxpayer following a GFC bailout – McEwan is seen to have personally led the rebuilding of the bank’s culture.

This experience will be crucial as he steers NAB through its cultural rebuild in the wake of the royal commission. For example, when he was appointed in July, McEwan said he was particularly proud of an indicator in the most recent RBS employee survey that showed staff had never felt safer to speak up.

That shift took five years to come through and no doubt he’ll be hoping for a speedier response at NAB. But the example emphasises why McEwan will put culture near the top of his priority list.

The second big priority for investors will be around costs. Under the three-year transformation plan announced by McEwan’s predecessor Andrew Thorburn in November 2017, NAB is aiming to cut $1 billion in costs, slash product numbers in half, cut IT applications by between 15 and 20 per cent and remove 4000 net jobs by the end of the 2020 financial year.

The bank has made good progress – as recently as NAB’s June quarter trading update we saw expenses had been held flat – and McEwan will no doubt be keen to finish the job.

But the market will be looking for what’s next.

In November 2017, Thorburn and chairman Ken Henry set the bank a long-term target of getting its cost-to-income ratio towards 35 per cent; on JP Morgan’s numbers it will sit at 46.6 per cent at September 30, falling to 43.3 per cent at the same time in 2020.

And while it is true that NAB’s target was set before the royal commission unleashed a barrage of new risk and compliance costs, the market will want to see whether McEwan and Chronican re-endorse the aspirational goal.

Getting towards a 35 per cent cost-to-income ratio would require some very hard and probably unpopular decisions. Slashing branch numbers – something McEwan has been prepared to do at RBS – would be an example.

The other question is what McEwan’s leadership team will look like as he tackles culture and costs. Banking sector history says changes are inevitable in this area.
description: When Ross McEwan arrives to take NAB's top job in December, the market will be watching for progress in two key areas.
